item.title: Cloudflare Outage Disrupts X, ChatGPT and Other Parts of the Internet
item.description: Services from Cloudflare, a software company, underpin thousands of websites, including X, Spotify and OpenAI. The company said a crash in a software system was to blame.

item.title: UN Support Bolsters Trump’s Gaza Plan but Road Ahead Is Still Rough
item.description: The Security Council’s backing offered a scaffolding of international legitimacy that will be needed to persuade countries to help see the plans through.

item.title: Live Updates: Trump to Host Saudi Leader, With Business and Stealth Jets on Agenda
item.description: President Trump will discuss security and investment with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, Saudi Arabia’s de facto ruler, who is making his first U.S. visit since 2018.

item.title: U.S. Military Threat Puts Spotlight on Venezuela’s Allies
item.description: American adversaries are unlikely to help President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela fend off a concerted attack. But they have made toppling him harder.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.description: The president is offering the crown prince fighter jets, a nuclear agreement and other deals as part of his efforts to collect investment and push forward on Middle East peace.

item.title: Trump Family’s Business Ties to Saudi Arabia Raise Ethics Worries
item.description: President Trump will host Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, Saudi Arabia’s de facto ruler, who oversees a major construction project that is in talks with the Trump family business.

item.title: Top U.N. Official Pushing to Get Aid Into Stricken Sudanese City
item.description: Paramilitaries accused of atrocities pledged to allow international aid and investigators into El Fasher, days after an airstrike hit a United Nations vehicle.

item.title: How We Linked the Auto Industry to Lead Poisoning in Nigeria
item.description: Blood and soil testing confirmed the health consequences. Then we tracked individual shipments to the United States.

item.title: Zelensky Will Try to Revive Peace Talks With Russia During Turkey Visit
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine says he has new proposals to kick-start negotiations with Russia that have been stalled for months.

item.title: Trump Administration Releases Thousands of Amelia Earhart Files
item.description: More than 4,000 documents related to Earhart were posted online, but scholars were not impressed. The release coincides with a period of intensified interest in the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein and his connection to the president.

item.title: Why Britain Is Embracing ‘Negative Nation Branding’
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer, trying to get a grip on a feverish immigration debate, is introducing a hard-line, contentious policy on refugees.

item.title: U.N. Security Council Adopts Trump’s Peace Plan for Gaza
item.description: Russia and China abstained in the vote, which provides a legal mandate for the Trump administration’s vision of how to move past the cease-fire to rebuild the war-ravaged enclave after two years of war.

item.title: The Real Cost of U.S. Car Batteries
item.description: We followed the supply chain for batteries used in millions of U.S. cars to villages in Nigeria where people are being poisoned by lead. Peter S. Goodman, who covers economics and geopolitics for The Times, describes our yearlong investigation.

item.title: Jeju Air Crash Investigators to Hold Public Hearing as They Face Criticism
item.description: With the cause of the disaster in South Korea still unclear after nearly a year, victims’ families have questioned the credibility and impartiality of the inquiry board.

item.title: At a Shared Symbol of Jihad, the Taliban Defy Their Old Ties With Pakistan
item.description: Afghan officials are lashing out against their former allies in the Pakistani military as hostilities between the two countries intensify.

item.title: Palestinian Voices Absent from U.S.-Run Center Planning Gaza’s Future
item.description: U.S. and Israeli soldiers, foreign diplomats and aid workers are congregated in a warehouse in central Israel to talk about the future of Gaza. One key group is missing: Palestinians.

item.title: Greenpeace Faces an Unusual New Legal Attack From a Pipeline Giant
item.description: The company that won a huge verdict against Greenpeace earlier this year has asked a North Dakota court to block a countersuit in the Netherlands.

item.title: Where Mao’s Peasants Tilled the Soil, Tourists Now Pay for the View
item.description: Decades ago, a Chinese village became an official symbol of revolutionary “self-reliance.” The slogan hasn’t changed, but nearly everything else has.

item.title: Trump and the ‘Donroe Doctrine’
item.description: The president is claiming a special U.S. sphere of influence in the Western Hemisphere.

item.title: Tanzania: What to Know About the Post-Election Violence
item.description: Post-election violence has tarnished the country’s reputation for stability, and the crackdown may have backfired on the government, as officials in Washington call for a re-examination of U.S. ties.

item.title: After Hundreds of Gazans Arrive on Mystery Flights, South Africa Asks How
item.description: A little-known group sold passage to desperate Palestinians who didn’t know their destination, catching the South African government by surprise.

item.title: Trump Gives Mixed Messages About Military Action Against Venezuela
item.description: President Trump said that he was open to talking with President Nicolás Maduro but that the United States has “to take care of Venezuela” as the U.S. builds a military force in the Caribbean.

item.title: Worker Error Is Faulted After Israeli-Born Canadian Hits Passport Snag
item.description: A student in Montreal, who was born in Kfar Saba, Israel, said she was initially told she could not list Israel as her birth country on her passport.

item.title: Trump Project in Maldives Opens More Doors for Cryptocurrency Investors
item.description: The Trump Organization and its Middle East development partner have announced a project in the Maldives that marries two of the family’s most successful moneymaking enterprises.

item.title: 25 Girls Abducted From School in Nigeria
item.description: The kidnapping echoed the abduction of the Chibok girls 11 years ago and came as U.S. officials pressed the country to address violence against Christians.

item.title: 2 Charged in Over 300 Thefts at Mausoleums in Toronto Area
item.description: The thefts took place during the daytime when the pair would enter mausoleums to swipe necklaces and other jewelry from remains, the authorities said.

item.title: Study Analyzes How Much ‘Macro’ Plastic Is Deadly to Sea Life
item.description: Scientists analyzed thousands of autopsies of seabirds, sea turtles and marine mammals and found that even small amounts of ingested plastic can be deadly.

item.title: Bangladesh Court Sentences Former Prime Minister to Death
item.description: Sheikh Hasina, who is in exile in India, was convicted in absentia of crimes against humanity in connection with a bloody crackdown on protests last year.

item.title: France Agrees to Sell Up to 100 Rafale Fighter Jets to Ukraine
item.description: Some in Ukraine criticized the 10-year timeline for the warplanes and other defense equipment, but France called it a long-term commitment to the country.

item.title: Serbian Woman Ends Hunger Strike Against Government
item.description: Dijana Hrka became the face of protest after her son and 15 other people died in a railway station collapse in Serbia. Her hunger strike lasted 16 days.

item.title: What Questions Do You Have About U.S. Immigration Policies?
item.description: “Ask a Correspondent” will take your questions to Hamed Aleaziz, our immigration reporter.

item.title: Man Who Rushed Ariana Grande in Singapore Gets 9 Days in Jail
item.description: He pleaded guilty to one charge of being a public nuisance.

item.title: A Plan for Private Jet Taxes Would Fund Climate Measures
item.description: A small group of countries is aiming to impose a fee on private jets and premium commercial fares. The revenue would help nations adapt to warming.

item.title: Senator Accuses Kenya of Neglecting Children Trapped in Saudi Arabia
item.description: The comments, by a member of Kenya’s ruling party, represent a rebuke of President William Ruto’s government: “Heads must roll.”

item.title: Ukraine’s Cash Is Running Low, and Europe Has No Good Plan B
item.description: The European Union wants to finance Ukraine’s war efforts using a loan based on Russia’s frozen assets in Belgium. If that falls through, there’s no easy alternative.

item.title: Polish Railway Explosion Was Sabotage, Prime Minister Says
item.description: Donald Tusk said unidentified saboteurs had tried to “blow up a train” on a route crucial for getting aid into Ukraine.

item.title: Drawing Religion Minister’s Ire, Music Video is Pulled by Universal in Malaysia
item.description: The minister criticized the girl band Dolla for wearing revealing outfits in a clip for their hit “Question.” He also threatened criminal action.

item.title: What Russian Activists Do When They Can’t Criticize Putin
item.description: Opposition-minded Russians who remain in the country are trying to keep politically active in whatever causes they can, whether that’s recycling, clean air or parking.

item.title: More Than 40 Indian Pilgrims Are Killed in Bus Crash in Saudi Arabia
item.description: The passengers, who were participating in the Umrah pilgrimage, were traveling between the two holiest cities in Islam, authorities said.

item.title: The ‘Donroe Doctrine’: Trump’s Bid to Control the Western Hemisphere
item.description: President Trump has tightened the U.S. grip on the Americas by rewarding allies and punishing rivals. That has upended the region’s politics.

item.title: Women Toiling in India’s Insufferable Heat Face Mounting Toll on Health
item.description: Prolonged exposure to hot weather can hinder people’s ability to lead safe and productive lives, experts say.

item.title: How Many People Die in India From Hot Weather? Nobody Really Knows.
item.description: Officials have yet to grasp the magnitude of heat-related deaths, let alone effectively deal with the problem, public health experts and scientists say.

item.title: Aiming to Shock Japan, China Pushes a Wave of Reprisals
item.description: Beijing is flexing its military and economic might to show its displeasure with the Japanese leader’s comments about defending Taiwan. But its aggressive approach risks backfiring.

item.title: Too Powerful to Ignore, Saudi Prince Returns to Washington’s Embrace
item.description: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman is to visit the White House on Tuesday for the first time since 2018, when the killing of a journalist by Saudi agents made him a pariah.

item.title: Thousands March for Climate Action as COP30 Talks Enter Second Week
item.description: As the talks continue, some countries are pushing for a detailed “road map” for a global transition away from oil, gas and coal.

item.title: Trump Gives Legs to South Korea’s Dream for Nuclear-Powered Subs
item.description: For decades, Washington blocked Seoul’s desire for the attack submarines over concerns about nuclear proliferation. President Trump reversed that policy last month, but left key questions unresolved.

item.title: Your Questions About Climate Change, Answered
item.description: You asked Somini Sengupta, our international climate reporter, about the science and the politics. She responded from COP30 in Brazil.

item.title: The Unlikely Mother of a Movement, on a Hunger Strike to Avenge Her Son
item.description: Since her son was killed with 15 others in a railway station collapse in Serbia, Dijana Hrka has become the face of widespread anti-government protests.

item.title: Trump-Style Candidate Heads to Runoff in Chile’s Election
item.description: The conservative José Antonio Kast will face Jeannette Jara, a Communist Party member, in a vote next month.

item.title: Latest U.S. Strike on Boat in Pacific Kills 3, Southern Command Says
item.description: The United States has carried out at least 21 strikes on boats the Trump administration accuses of smuggling drugs, killing at least 83 people.

item.title: Dozens of Australian Schools Close Over Asbestos Fears
item.description: Three-quarters of the schools in the area around the capital will be closed, although officials say the health risk from asbestos found in colored sand is low.

item.title: Friends Say a Suspect in the Louvre Heist Had Tried to Leave a Rough Past Behind
item.description: He had been best known as a daring urban dirt-bike rider who had pulled off stunts at iconic sites in Paris, according to several friends.

item.title: China Escalates Japan Feud With Island Patrols and Warnings to Citizens
item.description: China sent Coast Guard ships near disputed islands and warned travelers and students about safety risks in Japan. The escalation is over comments on Taiwan by Japan’s new prime minister.

item.title: Britain’s Labour Government Plans New, Tougher System for Asylum Seekers
item.description: Under the new rules, people granted asylum would have to wait 20 years, rather than the current five, before applying for permanent residency.

item.title: Women Describe Horrors They Endured in Assad’s Prisons
item.description: Under the Syrian dictator’s rule, the wives and children of rebels were seized as leverage. Some are now speaking about their trauma.

item.title: UN Climate Summit in Brazil Brings Tourism and Change to Belém’s Ver-o-Peso Market
item.description: A market central to a Brazilian port city’s culture and cuisine got a makeover for the U.N. Climate Change Conference. The results have thrilled some but angered others.

item.title: Protesters Rage Against Mexico’s Government Over Corruption and Violence
item.description: Members of Mexico’s Gen Z, as well as older protesters, demonstrated on Saturday in the wake of a high-profile assassination and rising anger over persistent violence.

item.title: Vatican to Return Indigenous Cultural Items to Canada Taken a Century Ago
item.description: Dozen of pieces used in a 1925 exhibition, including a whale-hunting kayak, will be returned to Canada early next month.

item.title: Pope Leo Urges Cinema Notables to Redouble Focus on Social Justice
item.description: But left unspoken at a Vatican meeting with film stars were the deep divisions over issues like abortion and homosexuality.

item.title: On a Clipped Wing, Flamingo Escapes a British Zoo for a Life in France
item.description: Frankie, a young Caribbean Flamingo, flew 130 miles from captivity. Her keepers said they would likely have to leave her in France.
